summary: As a users I want to be able to setup an ARM based Subutai Resource Host and create containers on it as they do on the x86_64 platform from ARM based images in snaps.
description:
Users shall be able to setup an ARM based Subutai Resource Host and create containers on it as they do on the x86_64 platform from ARM based images in snaps. The same capabilities present for x86_64 should also be mirrored on the ARM platform. This means having ARM based snaps available for the image hierarchy in the snap repository. The repository must be able to support multiple architectures in this way.

There are many ARM SoC's which have their own kernels so there will not be one single ARM platform to support: there will be many.

changelogList.author: Vyacheslav Kim
changelogList.toString: Jarvis Custom Workflow Merged with Automation

changelogList.toString:
Users shall be able to setup an ARM based Subutai Resource Host and create containers on it as they do on the x86_64 platform from ARM based images in snaps. The same capabilities present for x86_64 should also be mirrored on the ARM platform. This means having ARM based snaps available for the image hierarchy in the snap repository. The repository must be able to support multiple architectures in this way.

There are many ARM SoC's which have their own kernels so there will not be one single ARM platform to support: there will be many.

issues.summary: The user should clearly be able to differentiate between ARM arch Resource Hosts on the Subutai Management Console.
issues.description: to add

issues.summary: Research Snappy Ubuntu OEM package
issues.description:
Seem like  we need to use Snappy Ubuntu OEM packages for proper migration Subutai on ARM SoC. 
We need to research is it important for us, and how we can use it, what benefits we can get with it.

issueWorkLogs.comment:
[https://developer.ubuntu.com/en/snappy/guides/oem/]{quote}Branding
Branding can be set in the form of a slogan and an image. snappy and it’s
webdm counterpart will use this information to brand the system accordingly.{quote}We can specify Branding information in our package
issueWorkLogs.author: dshihovtsev

issueWorkLogs.comment:
[https://developer.ubuntu.com/en/snappy/guides/oem/]{quote}The oem snappy package is a snappy package type that is used to setup and
personalize the system according to an OEM.
It covers a broad range, such as the software stack with its configuration and
hardware enablement.
There can only be one snappy package of type: oem and it can only be
installed during image provision.{quote}We can use Snappy Ubuntu OEM package for initial configuration of our image for ARM SoC.
issueWorkLogs.author: dshihovtsev

issueWorkLogs.comment:
[https://developer.ubuntu.com/en/snappy/guides/oem/]{quote}dtb
The default dtb (device tree blob) can be overridden by a key entry point in
the package.yaml for the oem.
If a dtb is specified during provisioning, it will be selected as the dtb to
use for the system. If using an AB partition layout, when an update for the
oem package is installed which updates the dtb, the update will be
installed to the other partition and a reboot will be requested.{quote}We can ship device tree with oem snap. And it could be updated if required.
issueWorkLogs.author: dshihovtsev

issueWorkLogs.comment: [https://developer.ubuntu.com/en/snappy/guides/oem/]{quote}The oem snap can provide a set of default packages to be installed during either provisioning or first boot. {quote}Seems like we can embed snap packages into image
issueWorkLogs.author: dshihovtsev

issueWorkLogs.comment:
[https://developer.ubuntu.com/en/snappy/guides/oem/]{quote}Bootloaders
Since each system boots differently, assets that are currently provided in flashassets of the device package can be provided in the oem snap instead.{quote}We can include bootloader assets in OEM snap.
issueWorkLogs.author: dshihovtsev

issueWorkLogs.comment: [https://developer.ubuntu.com/en/snappy/start/]{quote}If you want to build against a local OEM snap, you need developer mode to disable signature verification:{quote}We can use local OEM snap package for building image.
issueWorkLogs.author: dshihovtsev

issueWorkLogs.comment: Snappy Ubuntu OEM snap package allows us to set all required environment for SoC. We can specify U-Boot environment file, include device tree, set branding information. We will use this package for creating images for SoC.
issueWorkLogs.author: dshihovtsev

annotations.quote:
dtb
The default dtb (device tree blob) can be overridden by a key entry point in
the package.yaml for the oem.
If a dtb is specified during provisioning, it will be selected as the dtb to
use for the system. If using an AB partition layout, when an update for the
oem package is installed which updates the dtb, the update will be
installed to the other partition and a reboot will be requested.

Since each system boots differently, assets that are currently provided in flashassets of the device package can be provided in the oem snap instead.

webdm counterpart will use this information to brand the system accordingly.

annotations.text: We can use local OEM snap package for building image.

It covers a broad range, such as the software stack with its configuration and

issues.summary: Prepare CURL for working with Snappy Ubuntu on ARM SoC
issues.description:
Since we have managed to execute Snappy Ubuntu on ARM SoC, we need to prepare all required packages for migration Subutai RH on this system.
As a fist package we need to prepare CURL with all required libs and dependencies for working with Snappy Ubuntu on ARM SoC.

issueWorkLogs.comment: CURL packages with all required libs for ARM added to repo. Binaries tested and works correctly.
issueWorkLogs.author: dshihovtsev

issues.summary: Automate uboot configuration to implement Snappy logic
issues.description: In case to have all Snappy "magic" (two loadable system and update rollback) we should have special uboot load command. Currently, we are configuring this command manually but to have solid Snappy on Parallella we should automate it. Find out how we can do it and implement.

changelogList.author: Timur Zununbekov
changelogList.toString: This issue links to "Wiki Page (Subutai Confluence)"

issueWorkLogs.comment: We have passed Snappy Ubuntu logic in file that contains all required environment variables. The only steps to be done manually is load environment from this file. Steps described here: https://confluence.subutai.io/display/SNAP/Snappy+Ubuntu+on+Parallella
issueWorkLogs.author: tzununbekov

issues.summary: BTRFS partition issue on Parallella
issues.description: Snappy Ubuntu that we use to run on Parallella by default has four primary disk partition - boot, system-a, system-b and writable. Partition table doesn't support more than four primary partitions, so we cannot just create another one, but to run Subutai we should have one extra partition for BTRFS volume. Find the way to create additional partition table in SD card for Snappy Subutai on Parallella

issueWorkLogs.comment:
After some investigating we found out that we have two possible solutions: convert MBR to GPT or create extended partition on SD. 
Converting MBR to GPT probably is not possible without data loss so we have tried to create extended partition in place of writable partition. After tests we got the conclusion - this way fit our requirements and we will use it
issueWorkLogs.author: tzununbekov

issues.summary: Prepare OVS to run on ARM Resourch Host
issues.description: Find the optimal way to port OVS to ARM architecture to make possible run Resource Host on Parallella. Possible solutions - rebuild OVS with ARM architecture support or get ready-to-use ARM packages.

issues.summary: Support Parallella/ODROID/Beagle Bone/Raspberry v2
issues.description:
At least one of these is mandatory, they are ordered by priority.

*NOTE*: The Beagle Bone is already supported by Snappy so I think it might be very easy.
*NOTE*: Some NoSQL databases have issues on ARM 32-bit platforms so there will not be support for them like MongoDB which requires a 64-bit address space. No need to create snaps for their images.

issues.summary: Research Snappy Ubuntu on ARM
issues.description: According to plan of IoT preparation for Subutai we should research the Snappy Ubuntu opportunity to run on ARM based hardware

changelogList.author: Timur Zununbekov
changelogList.toString: This issue is cloned by SS-3613

changelogList.author: Timur Zununbekov
changelogList.fromString: This issue is subtask of SS-3611

changelogList.author: Timur Zununbekov
changelogList.toString: This issue is subtask of SS-3611

issueWorkLogs.comment: According to the information from links above, we can port Snappy Ubuntu to Parallella. Going to try run it with BB's rootfs and Parallella's kernel.
issueWorkLogs.author: tzununbekov

issueWorkLogs.comment:
http://kernel.ubuntu.com/git/ppisati/ubuntu-vivid.git/tree/arch/arm/configs/snappy?h=snappy_packaging

{quote}Mode	Name	Size	
-rw-r--r--	generic.config	1273	logplain
-rw-r--r--	lxc.config	        399	        logplain
-rw-r--r--	security.config	565	        logplain
-rw-r--r--	snappy.config	408	        logplain
-rw-r--r--	systemd.config	731	        logplain{quote}

Kernel configs to enable Snappy support. Need to compare with Parallella kernel config
issueWorkLogs.author: tzununbekov

issueWorkLogs.comment: [https://ograblog.wordpress.com/2015/01/25/porting-ubuntu-snappy-to-a-yet-unsupported-armhf-board/]{quote}By default the whole u-boot logic in a snappy system gets read and executed from a file called snappy-system.txt living in the /boot partition of your install{quote}Seems like we should configure Parallella environment to load custom OS instead of using file on mmc
issueWorkLogs.author: tzununbekov
tzununbekov
tzununbekov
tzununbekov

issueWorkLogs.comment:
http://kernel.ubuntu.com/git/ppisati/ubuntu-vivid.git/log/?h=snappy_packaging

got link to Snappy repository from Ubuntu developers. Lot's of interesting thing to dig
issueWorkLogs.author: tzununbekov

issueWorkLogs.comment: [https://ograblog.wordpress.com/2015/01/25/porting-ubuntu-snappy-to-a-yet-unsupported-armhf-board/]{quote}It is also very likely that the commands in your snappy-system.txt are to new for your installed u-boot (or are simply not enabled in its build configuration) so we might need to override them with equivalent functions your bootloader actually supports (i.e. fatload vs load or bootm vs bootz).{quote}Parallella's uboot doesn't support some of new command from Snappy configuration so we should rewrite some of them
issueWorkLogs.author: tzununbekov

issues.summary: Research Snappy Ubuntu on ARM
issues.description: According to plan of IoT preparation for Subutai we should research the Snappy Ubuntu opportunity to run on ARM based hardware

issueWorkLogs.comment: [https://developer.ubuntu.com/en/snappy/guides/porting/]{quote}your bootloader logic must pick the kernel, initrd and dtb from the a/ directory on your system-boot partition.{quote}We can use own kernel adopted to any device with snappy.
issueWorkLogs.author: dshihovtsev

issueWorkLogs.comment: Seems like Snappy Ubuntu could be installed on a wide range of ARM SoC. We can use own kernel if required to use any device specific mechanisms.
issueWorkLogs.author: dshihovtsev

issueWorkLogs.comment: [https://developer.ubuntu.com/en/snappy/guides/porting/]{quote}download the device tarball of our beaglebone reference build used for 15.04 release.{quote}We need to download beaglebone image to use it as rootfs
issueWorkLogs.author: dshihovtsev

issueWorkLogs.comment: [https://developer.ubuntu.com/en/snappy/guides/porting/]{quote}“System A/B” is a Snappy feature to have two sets of root filesystems and boot files (typically kernel, initrd and optionally fdt/device tree), hence “A/B”. When an update breaks the system preventing it from boot to a healthy state, snappy will automatically fall back to the previously use system. Read this section to achieve this setup with Snappy and U-Boot.{quote}And we need to reconfigure uboot to fit snappy logic.
issueWorkLogs.author: dshihovtsev

issueWorkLogs.comment: [https://developer.ubuntu.com/en/snappy/guides/porting/]{quote}$ sudo dd if=my-snappy.img of=/dev/sdX bs=32M{quote}Write it to flash drive
issueWorkLogs.author: dshihovtsev

annotations.quote: your bootloader logic must pick the kernel, initrd and dtb from the a/ directory on your system-boot partition.
annotations.text: We can use own kernel adopted to any device with snappy.

Following official guide for installation Ubuntu on Parallella board we can easily install it, and start. 
https://www.parallella.org/quick-start/
Serial port allows to control boot process and allow to prevent unknown errors during boot. 

Ubuntu was successfully installed on Parallella board.

issueWorkLogs.author: tzununbekov

issues.summary: Try to migrate Snappy on Parallella board
issues.description:
Since we are planning to support ARM architecture, we need to investigate ability to run Snappy Ubuntu on Parallella board. 
All Snappy Ubuntu functionality must be supported by this installation.

changelogList.author: Timur Zununbekov
changelogList.toString: This issue links to "Wiki Page (Subutai Confluence)"

changelogList.author: Dmitry Shihovtsev
changelogList.fromString: CLONE - Try to migrate Snappy on Parallella board
changelogList.toString: Try to migrate Snappy on Parallella board

issueWorkLogs.comment: As a result of research we have found out that any Ubuntu-like system can be ported to Parallella board or any other board with uboot loader. Firstly, we have managed to run our custom kernel with Snappy's rootfs but main Snappy's features was missing. After some discussion with Canonical developers team we made the conclusion that we don't have correct uboot environment and init ram disk. Finally, we found correct configuration for all parts of Snappy kernel and rootfs, rebuild kernel and now we have Snappy Ubuntu on Parallella.
issueWorkLogs.author: tzununbekov

issues.summary: Coordinate works on ARM support feature
issues.description:
In the course of implementing requirements for the next release, we need to coordinate works on ARM based RH support feature. We need to review and test the following hw boards:
# Parallela
# Odroid
# Raspberry v2
# Beagle Bone
If needed we shoud buy necessary hw and run tests. The ultimate goal is to be able to use at least one of the boards above as a Subutai Resource Host. To verify this we should be able at least to:
* Install Ubuntu or Ubuntu Snappy on the board
* Run Subutai go-agent
* Clone a container from a big data product template such as Hadoop as a part of an environment
* Setup networking and N2N

If these steps are done then we can conclude that the board can be used as a RH.

issueWorkLogs.comment:
[https://www.parallella.org/quick-start/]{quote}1. Ensure that you have the required accessories

A high quality 2000mA rated 5V DC power supply with 5.5mm OD / 2.1mm ID center positive polarity plug.
A micro HDMI to HDMI cable.
A USB male Micro-B to female Standard-A cable.
An ethernet cable
A fan (highly recommended!){quote}Prerequirements
issueWorkLogs.author: dshihovtsev

issueWorkLogs.comment:
After preparing flash drive, we can load system with standard configuration. 

Parallella board can be loaded with prepared Ubuntu distributive. It easily to install it following official documentation.
issueWorkLogs.author: dshihovtsev

issueWorkLogs.comment: [http://www.parallella.org/create-sdcard/]{quote}These headless Ubuntu distributions represent the latest official releases of the firmware and is recommended for anyone using the Parallella for software development and research.{quote}Write flash drive with headless Ubuntu image
issueWorkLogs.author: dshihovtsev
